A. Débora est née vers 1979 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique du BENIN, d’où elle est originaire. Débora est mariée et mère d’un garçon de trois (3) ans qui est à la maternelle. Débora vend des chaussures à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin depuis sept (7) ans. C’est à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays frontalier au Bénin que Débora achète ses chaussures. Débora a déjà bénéficié de crédits de la part de ALIDé pour développer son activité. Actuellement, Débora sollicite un autre crédit pour continuer de développer son activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. 
	.
texts.en:
A. Débora was born around 1979 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of Benin, to where she traces her roots. She is married and the mother of a 3-year-old boy who is in nursery school. She has been selling shoes at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin, for seven years. Lomé, the capital of Togo, a country bordering Benin, is where Debora purchases her shoes. She has already benefited from a loan from ALIDÉ to develop her business. Currently, she's requesting another loan to continue developing it, in order to respond better to customer demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy five boxes of shoes

loans.name: Kosar Parveen Muhammad Tariq Group

texts.en:
Kosar Parveen baji is the leader of a group of three women, all residents of Kasur, Pakistan, a city famous for its shrines. Her husband runs a leather-selling business, a very profitable enterprise because most people in Kasur wear “Khussa,” a kind of leather footwear. Kosar baji and her members also run their own businesses selling kites which are very popular with children, thereby enabling them to pay for utilities. Kosar baji is now applying for a loan to buy leather to increase the profit of her husband’s leather-selling business, while Rasheeda baji and Sugran baji and Ailas baji each want a loan to buy leather to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the others are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather to resell.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhoen Toem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of 27 members, is located in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province. Its members plan to use this loan for different purposes. They have elected Mrs. SokhoE. T. as the village bank president. She is a grocer who owns a small store. Since her business is doing well, she has many of customers who have a variety of demands. She has requested this loan to purchase more goods for her store to support her customers' needs. In doing so, she hopes to increase her income and improve her business.

Her husband, Mr. H. Vachar, uses a motorbike with cart to deliver goods to earn money. Mrs. SokhoE. T. is 29 years old and the mother of two childrE., one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too yoU. to work or study.

loans.use: To request a loan to purchase more grocery products to support her customers.

loans.name: Ansu

texts.en: Ansu H. is 27 years old, married and has three children. Two of her children are in school and the youngest is still breastfeeding. She is married to a teacher in a school in the community where they live. To support her household, she sells cosmetics to loyal clients in her neighborhood. She also sells various kinds of food, which she prepares every morning. Ansu switches to the sale of cosmetics in the afternoon. She says that selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory and increase her sales and income. Ansu is applying for this loan to buy bags of maize, fish and vegetables as well as cosmetics.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and bags of maize and other food items

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen makes a living selling various types of food and drinks. She is 50 years old, married and has four children. She is applying for this loan to buy more items to sell, and expresses her thanks and appreciation to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more food items and drinks

loans.name: Bujwaha Marriam Kasime Group

texts.en: Marriam K. is 37 years old, married, and has twelve children, all of whom are in school. She looks after one dependent in her family. She has been selling new clothes for over 8 years; at times the profits are less because of less capital. She is now using the loan to purchase new clothes specifically for gents such as shirts, trousers, pants, ties, etc. in large quantities to increase profits in her business. She loves seeing her community prosper, especially women. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy clothes in bulk for resale

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de gblinkomé. Son mari est un déclarant en douane, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle a commencé ce commerce en 2007 et s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays. Son stock a diminué, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner, elle a  déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite son deuxième crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 25 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This is a woman who is married and the mother of two children. She lives with her family in the Gblinkomé district. Her husband is a customers agent. She earns an income from commerce in charcoal, a business she started in 2007. She supplies herself from inland locations. Because her inventory has shrunk, she would like to stock up again. She has already obtained a loan from WAGES and has repaid it. She's requesting a second loan to resupply herself with 25 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Bushra Muhammad Afzal Group

texts.en:
Bushra baji is the leader of a loan group that includes eight other women from her locality. Bushra baji is a very hardworking lady who sells kites. She has chosen this business because it’s profitable and people retain interest in flying kites. Bushra baji works to help ease the financial burden of her husband, who buys leather and sells it to factories. Bushra baji is applying for a loan to buy leather to help increase her husband's profits.

The other members of the group also have goals for this loan.

Saima baji and Zareena baji each want a loan to buy leather to resell.
Sakina baji wants a loan to buy timber to sell. 
Sugran baji wants a loan to buy another motorbike for her bike rental business.
Salma baji wants a loan to buy another video game for her video game shop.
Parveen Fatima baji wants a loan to buy kites for her kite sales business. 
Kareema baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones for her mobile phone sales business. 
Shahida Parveen baji wants a loan to buy goats to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather to sell

loans.name: Seyman Gull Group

texts.en: Seyman Gull leads a loan group that includes three other members. They live in District 11, Kabul, Afghanistan. Seyman Gull and Khalada want to take out a loan to buy necessary materials for their general store. Fowrozan is requesting a loan to buy new machine for her tailoring business. Abdull Baser wants a loan to expand his fruit store. Together, they are very happy with this loan. Help these poor people in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy goods for a general store

loans.name: Bariatou

texts.fr: D. Bariatou est née en 1972 à BASSILA une ville du Nord du BENIN dans le Département de la Donga. Bariatou est mariée à YACOUBOU Mohame. Bariatou est mère de cinq (5) enfants dont quatre (4) garçons et une fille tous scolarisés. Bariatou réside avec sa famille à Suru Léré, un quartier très populaire de la ville de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Bariatou vend devant son domicile des sacs de charbon de bois depuis douze (12) ans ainsi que de la nourriture (riz). C’est  dans le Centre et au  Nord du BENIN que Bariatou achète ses sacs de charbon. Quand au riz et condiments pour le préparer, Bariatou les achète à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Bariatou a déjà eu quatre crédits de ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a très bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener son activité à un stade supérieur. Aujourd’hui encore Bariatou sollicite un cinquième crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter le volume de son activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle sans cesse croissante.
texts.en:
D. Bariatou was born in BASSILA, a city of northern Benin and in Donga County. She is married to YACOUBOU Mohame and is the mother of five children, four boys and a girl who are all in school. Bariatou resides with her family in Suru Léré, a highly-populated district of the city of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. For twelve years, Bariatou has been selling sacks of charcoal, as well as rice, in front of her home. Central and northern Benin are where she purchases her sacks of charcoal. As for the rice and the condiments for cooking it, she purchases them at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. Bariatou has already had four loans from ALIDÉ and has indeed repaid them, having used them to raise her business to a higher level. Today, she's requesting a fifth loan from ALIDÉ to augment her business volume in order to respond better to the demands of her ever-increasing customer base.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy forty sacks of charcoal, a sack of rice, and ingredients that go into making tomato sauce

loans.name: Zachariah

texts.en:
Zachariah is forty-five years old. He is married and a father with four children. His wife is a farmer and all his children are in school in the community where they live. He has been a general photographer for the past ten years. He also sells ointment for skin rashes.

He owns a photography and video shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also travels to occasions like parties and concerts to take photographs of his clients. He requests the loan to enable him buy additional tools and materials like a camera, flash, video camera and other things to expand his operations. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: For additional photography equipment

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson U. A. sells pepper soup to people within his community in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. He is 35 years old and married with 2 children. He has been in this business for a long time. He hopes for the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase pepper soup ingredients. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pepper soup ingredients

loans.name: Anwar Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Anwar baji is married to Mr R.,and together they have lived in Kasur, Pakistan, a city famous for its shrines, for the past ten years. Anwar baji fills small packets with various spices and sells them in her community. She earns a good income from this business and can pay the utility bills easily. Mr R. runs a leather business. In Kasur most people come into contact with leather-selling businesses because people wear 'Khussa', a traditional kind of footwear made from leather. Anwar baji is applying for a loan to buy leather to expand her husband’s leather-selling business.

Anwar baji is the leader of a group loan that includes six other women. Naziran baji, Salma baji, Nazia baji, Zainab baji, Bable Shaheen baji and Ayesha baji each want a loan to buy leather to sell.

As this is a group loan, the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather to sell

loans.name: Harriet Nakalembe‘S Group

texts.en:
Harriet is the leader of four members of a group. She is 37 years old and married with five children aged between 5 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Harriet takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Harriet resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Harriet sells secondhand clothes in Owino Market. She sells to an average of fifteen people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week.

Harriet buys clothes from Owino, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city, and pays for transportation costs to and from work. Her major monthly expenses include rent for the business premises and electricity. She has been in this business for the last six years. Her main challenges are thieves and seasonality.

Harriet has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothes to sell. Harriet is aspiring to own a permanent shop for her business.

loans.use: To buy more used-clothing to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sareth Teav Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-six people living in Popeal Khae village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Sareth T. is the 45-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who rents land from another villager to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Unfortunately, the field she tills isn't very fertile, which affects her crops. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. 

Mrs. Sareth T.'s husband, Mr. Sao SoeU., is a motorbike taxi driver. Together, they have seven children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, while another is a motorbike taxi driver. The others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to feed her vegetables.

loans.name: Mériga

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle a associé à ce commerce la vente de tubercules. Elle a débuté ce commerce en 1974, ce qui fait qu’elle a une maîtrise de la gestion de ce commerce. Elle s’approvisionne au nord du Togo plus précisément dans la ville de Badou. Une partie de son stock est épuisé, voulant le rehausser, elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 15 sacs de charbons de bois et 10 tas d’ignames.
texts.en:
This is a lady who earns an income from commerce in charcoal. She has included along with it the sale of tubers. She started this business in 1974, which means she has a command of this commerce. She stocks up in northern Togo, in the city of Badou to be precise. A portion of her inventory is exhausted. Wanting to replenish it, she's requesting her first loan from WAGES to buy fifteen sacks of charcoal and ten tubs of yams.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal and some yams

loans.name: Hamidan Mairaj Din Group

texts.en:
Hamidan baji is the wife of M. D. and has lived in Kasur, Pakistan, for the past twenty years. Kasur is famous for its shrines and for its sweetmeats. Her husband runs a construction supplies business. The building contractors give him orders and he fulfills those order and earns income.

Hamidan baji runs a paranda-making business. A paranda is an item to tie back the hair tightly. She makes different kinds of parandas, both simple and embroidered, and sells them in the community. Hamidan baji is a helpful resource to her husband because he feels comfortable with her and trusts her expertise. She is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies to complete the orders of her husband’s customers. 

Hamidan baji is the group leader of three other women from her locality:

Allah rakhi baji wants a loan to buy timber to sell.

Kosar parveen baji wants a loan to buy leather to sell.

Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy material (thread and beads) for her paranda-making business.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina Serwaa is 26 years old. She is divorced and has given birth to one child. She currently lives with her daughter who is in school in the community where they live. She lives at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She sells bags of maize and groundnuts.

Faustina has been in this business for over two years now. She goes and gets maize from the remote areas because she feels those areas are cheaper. She treks to Kumasi and Accra to sell it. She buys her goods from the farmers just to avoid middlemen. She says she sells at the market square sometimes.

Faustina wants a loan to increase her working capital so that her dream of buying goods in bulk can be achieved. In this way, she can supply to a large number of customers to increase her market size, hence, her profit. She is hoping to receive a loan from you for a business upgrade.

loans.use: To buy maize in bulk

loans.name: Salam Malik Muhammad Din Group

texts.en:
My name is Salam and I have lived in Kasur, Pakistan, for the past fifteen years. Kasur city is famous for its shrines and for its sweetmeats.

I run a paranda-making business.  A paranda is an item used to tie back the hair tightly. I can prepare simple and stitched parandas easily, and then I sell them in the community to earn income. My husband name is M. M. D. who is a daily-wage laborer. I do this business to manage the financial expenses because my husband’s earnings are insufficient. I am applying for a loan to buy material (thread, beads) to expand my paranda-making business. 

I’m the group leader of three other women from my locality:

Rasheeda baji wants a loan to buy leather for her shoe-making business.

Farhat baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business.

Sakina baji wants a loan to buy material (thread and beads) for her paranda-making business.

loans.use: To buy thread and beads for her paranda-making business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing is a photographer. He is 40 years old and married with no children. He hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase a digital camera and film. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a digital camera and film

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama P. is 54 years old. She is married and has five children; four of them are in school whilest the eldest has completed senior high school. She lives with her family at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and sells banku with soup.

Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many Ghanaians as breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to raise increased income to support her business and include the sale of cereals in bags to her customer which she has started on a small scale. She has been in business for thirty years now. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Gyedie mu Aba’.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood

loans.name: Nafissath

texts.fr: Y. Nafissath est née le 16/02/1987 à Cotonou, Nafissath est mariée à DJIVO Ignace. Nafissath et Ignace ont deux enfants tous à leur charge.  Le premier enfant est  scolarisé et le second est encore au biberon. Nafissath vend des articles de mercerie dans sa boutique à Dandji vers Dégakon, un quartier populaire de la ville de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. C'est au Nigeria, État frontalier au Bénin que Nafissath va faire ses achats. Nafissath a déjà eu plusieurs crédits de ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a très bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener son activité à un stade supérieur. Aujourd’hui encore Nafissath sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter le volume de son activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle sans cesse croissante.
texts.en:
Y. Nafissath was born on February 16, 1987 in Cotonou. Nafissath is married to Djivo Ignace. Nafissath and Ignace are raising two children. Their first child is in school and the second is still an infant. Nafissath sells sewing supplies in her little shop in Dandji on the way to Dégakon, a working-class neighborhood of the city of Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Nafissath does her buying in Nigeria, a border state of Benin. She has had several loans from ALIDé. She reimbursed them correctly and managed to use them to advance her business. Today, Nafissath is requesting a new loan from ALIDé to increase the volume of her business so as to better respond to the demand of her ever-growing clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 5 rolls of poplin, 20 little cartons of sewing thread, 10 packs of buttons, a machine to make pressed buttons, and one carton of accessories

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina P. is 42 years old. She is married and blessed with five children. Currently two have completed the senior high school and the rest are still schooling. Sakina says combining motherhood and business demands is very challenging. However the two must be attended to simultaneously. She has been selling bulk supplies of fresh and dried peppers for five years now. She buys the peppers, dries and mills them to get the powdered form she sells.

She treks to the nearest city centers like Kumasi to sell. She is able to support her household well through this business. She needs the loan to enable her to purchase more stocks of peppers. She hopes the loan would enable her to double her savings to provide quality education for the kids.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of fresh peppers

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama G., a 47-year-old woman, is divorced and mother of six children. Three of her children are in school currently. She operates a footwear shop at Dorma, in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Ama has been selling brand new shoes, ladies' wear, slippers and dressing bags to support her family for the past three years now. However, she operates on a small scale due to lack of funds.

With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into her business to achieve progress. She believes the loan would support her to be more resourced to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory. She wants to use the loan to purchase more clothing materials, ladies' wear, shoes, and slippers. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase brand new shoes, ladies' wear and slippers

loans.name: Kyarwabuyamba A Ahebwa Margaret Group

texts.en: A. Margaret is a 32-year-old married woman with five children, all schooling. She has been selling new clothes for over 2 years. She is using the loan to purchase clothes for ladies, gentlemen, abd children. She is a hard-working business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a residential house.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for ladies, gentlemen, and children

loans.name: Sabine

texts.fr: S. Sabine est née vers 1973 à Ekpè dans la Commune de Sèmè-Kpodji. Sabine est mariée à HOUESSOU Tierrie, un mécanicien de profession. Sabine est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Sabine vend de l'huile en bidons de vingt cinq (25) litres et en bouteille d'un litre ainsi que du maïs en détail à domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Sabine va s'approvisionner en ses différents produits. Sabine n'arrive pas à satisfaire toutes les demandes de sa clientèle par manque de moyens financiers suffisants. Alors, Sabine s'est rapprochée de ALIDé pour avoir de crédit afin de mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
S. Sabine was born around 1973 in Ekpè in the township of Sèmè-Kpodji. Sabine is married to Houesou Tierrie, a professional mechanic. Sabine is the mother of 3 children, all enrolled in school. She sells oil in jerry cans of 25 liters and in bottles of 1 liter, as well as selling maize retail, out of her home. She goes to Dantokpa, the big international market of Benin, to stock up on her products. Sabine is not able to satisfy the needs of her clientele because she does not have sufficient financial means. So she has come to ALIDé to have a loan so as to better serve her clients.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of four jerry cans of 25 liters of peanut oil and a sack of 50 kg of maize

loans.name: Bilquis Muhammad Ali Group

texts.en:
Bilquis baji is the wife of M. A.. They have lived in Kasur, Pakistan, for the past 14 years. Kasur city is famous for its shrines and sweetmeat. Her husband is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver and earns income. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw. Bilquis baji operates a thread-selling business. She gets thread from old clothes and after washing it, makes a roll of thread and sells it to shops. After that struggle she earns income. Bilquis baji is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw because it has a problem and needs urgent repairs because its engine seizes.

She is the group leader of four other women from her area. Rehana baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe-selling business. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Anayat baji and Suraiya baji each want loans to buy material (beads and thread) for their Paranda-making business. (Paranda is an item to tie back the hair tightly.)

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair the auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is married and the mother of one child. She lives at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana with her family. She is 23 years old. She runs a mini shop and has been selling items like blouses and skirts, women's slippers and dressing bags for the past year. She gets her stock of goods from Kumasi which is the nearest city center but she is unable to bring back more.

Patricia is constrained by lack of funds for the business. She needs this loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Asomdwe’ which means Peace.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies wear, and slippers

loans.name: Kyarwabuyamba A Animu Bangamba Group

texts.en: Animu B. is aged 44 and a single mother of four kids, all schooling. She has been operating her business of selling restaurant items for over three years but she does not have a refrigerator for perishables. She is using the loan to purchase restaurant items like food (bananas, meat, millet flour, maize flour, etc). She is an active entrepreneur, whose dream is to obtain a refrigerator for perishables and construct another house.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant items like food (bananas, meat, millet flour, maize flour, etc).

loans.name: Abraham Plus Group

texts.fr: Jérôme O. est devenu micro entrepreneur depuis 1982. Il avait commencé à vendre des babouches avec un capital initial de $5. De 1993 en 1997, il est passé par plusieurs activités commerciales notamment l’échange des monnaies,  la vente de maїs et des braises. En 2006, il décide de s’acheter le premier moulin lequel au bout de deux ans et grâce aux bénéfices accumulés lui ont permis de s’acheter un deuxième jusqu’à ce jour. Ses activités se situent dans un quartier nordique et le plus peuplé de Kinshasa. Vu le nombre croissant de sa clientèle, Jérôme a planifié d’acheter avec le crédit du mois de mai courant un troisième moulin en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Actuellement, son affaire lui génère un bénéfice de $75 par semaine. La difficulté qu’il rencontre dans son activité est la coupure intempestive de l’électricité. Jérôme pense s’acheter avec les prochains crédits un groupe électrogène dans le but de servir à tout moment ses clients et générer plus de bénéfice. Il est âgé de 43 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants âgés de 5 à 12 ans. Deux seulement d’entre eux vont à l’école. Il est membre fidèle d’un des groupes de Hope RDC dénommé « Abraham ». Son rêve est d’ouvrir un jour une petite minoterie pour la population de son quartier.
texts.en:
Jérôme O. became a micro-entrepreneur in 1982. He began by selling flip-flops with an initail capital of US$ 5. From 1993-1997, he tried out various commercial activities, notably exchanging currencies, selling maize, and selling charcoal.

In 2006, he bought his first mill. At the end of two years and thanks to the profit from that mill, he was able to buy a second that he still uses today. His business is situated in a northern district, the most populous of Kinshasa. In vue of his growing clientele, Jérôme has planned to use this month-of-May loan to buy a third mill so as to further increase his earnings. Presently, his business is bringing in a profit of US$ 75 per week.

The difficulty he encounters in his business is untimely power outages. Jérôme intends to buy a generator with later loans so as to be able to serve his clients at all times and thus earn more money. He is 43, married and father of 3 children, aged between 5 and 12. Only two are enrolled in school. He is a faithful member of one of the HOPE DRC groups named "Abraham". His dream is to open a real flour mill for the people living in his district.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy a third mill so as to increase his profits

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena started her fish sales ten years ago at Dorma in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Abena prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She has a cunning spirit to convince her suppliers to sell her more fish when there is high demand for fish and supply is low. She buys stocks of fish from the cold stores in Kumasi and smokes them at a nearby stand. She has a high customer base, lots of customers that buy from her stand. They buy from her both fresh fish and smoked fish.

Abena is now 40 years old, married, and a mother with a child who is currently working. She requests the loan to upgrade her stock of goods; like this, she believes she can buy more fish to prevent her from frequent traveling to Kumasi. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Asomdwe’ which means Peace.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of smoked fish and dried fish

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr: Kokoè est mariée et mère d’un jeune garçon, son mari est un policier à la retraite. Afin d’aider son époux dans les charges du foyer, elle a entamé en 2003 le commerce de céréales, elle vend les céréales en gros et en détail. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de badou parce que dans cette ville les prix des céréales sont moins coûteux. Le stock dont elle dispose ne lui permet pas de faire face à la demande de ses clients. Elle veut augmenter son stock et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 10 sacs de maïs, 12 sacs d’haricots et 5 sacs de mil.
texts.en:
Kokoè is married and the mother of a little boy. Her husband is a retired policeman. So as to help her husband support the family, she began selling cereals in 2003, both wholesale and retail. She buys her supplies in the country, in the town of Badou, because the price of cereals is less expensive there. Her present stock does not allow her to cover the needs of her clientele. She would like to increase her inventory and is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 10 sacks of maize, 12 sacks of dried beans, and 5 sacks of millet.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize, dried beans, and millet

loans.name: Viviane

texts.fr:
G. Viviane est née le 02/12/1966 dans le Département du Mono. Viviane est mariée à ZANCLAN Euloge. 
Viviane et Euloge ont deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Viviane vend des tissus et des articles de mercerie à domicile. C'est à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays frontalier au Bénin et au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin que Viviane fait ses achats. Viviane a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits de la part de ALIDé pour développer son activité. Actuellement, Viviane sollicite un troisième crédit pour continuer de développer son activité afin de fidéliser sa clientèle.
texts.en:
G. Viviane was born on December 2, 1966 in the county of Mono. She is married to Zanclan Euloge. Viviane and Euloge are raising two children, both enrolled in school. Viviane sells cloth and other sewing necessities out of her home. She does her buying in Lomé, the capital of Togo, a border state of Benin, and in Nigeria, a neighbor of Benin. She has already had 2 loans from ALIDé to develop her business. Presently, Viviane is requesting a third loan to continue to develop her business so as to keep her clientele faithful. son activité afin de fidéliser sa clientèle.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 20 lengths of 12 meters each of Hitarget cloth

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia sells foodstuffs, firewood and drinks. She is 60 years old and she is a widow with 8 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N 120,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell.She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Uyimwen

texts.en: Uyimwen is 48 years old and married with three children. She is a caterer who bakes cakes for all occasions. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more catering materials like flour, sugar and baking powder. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more catering materials

loans.name: Habiba Group

texts.en: Habiba is the group leader of the Habiba group, which has three members. They requested a loan of 28000 Afghan. They live in 15 Kabul, Afghanistan. Habiba and Abdull Ahmad want a loan to expand their fresh-fruit businesses. Najwa wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. She wants to buy a new machine for her business. With this loan, they can all make their businesses grow to support their families and make a better future for themselves and for their families.

loans.use: To expand and progress their businesses

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina P. is married but does not have children. She is a 24-year-old trader and her husband is a taxi driver. She trades in lace materials, textiles and clothing materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations.  For lack of adequate working capital, Sakina buys a small amount of lace material and sells through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk amount of lace material and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to rent a store to trade. She belongs to a village bank called "Asomdwe," which means Peace.

loans.use: To purchase bulk amount of lace materials and textiles

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua S. is 35 years old and married. She takes care of her little sister’s daughter. Akua has managed to send the child to one the best schools in the community where she lives with her husband, who is a photographer. She lives in Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. To support her household, she hawks and sells cosmetics in her neighborhood to her loyal clients. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income for the family’s needs. She is therefore appealing for your assistance to make good sales and take care of her home. She also belongs to the village bank called "Asomdwe," which means Peace.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of cosmetics

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet S. sells medicines to make a living. She is 36 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thanks to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 55 years old and married with 6 children. She owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Mrs. Luzminda F. is a Paglaum member in good standing under PDP-LP program since August 31, 2009. Married to Juanito F. and blessed with 4 children, she's requesting her loan amounting to 16,000 pesos for the purpose of additional capital for her business, a "sari-sari store" (variety store) She wants to buy additional stock for her "sari-sari" store. Her plan for her family is to send her children through school until college and to build a new house.

loans.use: additional capital for sari-sari store

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Mrs. Jocelyn C. has been a member since August 17, 2004, and is a bonafide resident of Trucat Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. At 34 years old, she is married and blessed with 3 children. Recently, she's requesting her 6th loan in the amount of 4,000 php that will be used as additional capital for her banana vending. She's thankful to Paglaum Coop for allowing her to borrow money that will be used for additional capital for said project.

loans.use: additional capital for her banana vending

loans.name: Florica

texts.en: Mrs. Florica A., a Paglaum member under PDP-LP program, resides at Minlasag Sibutad, Zamboanga Del Norte. She has been a member since March 10, 2008. Her husband died 3 years ago. She is requesting a loan amounting to 3,000 pesos to have additional capital for her "Sari-sari" (variety) store. Her plan for the business is to improve and grow her business. Future plans for her family are to see her children finish school until college and someday find a decent and stable job.

loans.use: Purchase addtional grocery items

loans.name: Nafisa

texts.en:
Nafisa Y. is single. She recently completed senior high school but for lack of money she could not continue to the university as had been her dream. She lives with her parent in a rented apartment. She is 24 years old and a businesswoman. She is a very hard-working lady who wants to cater for herself.

Nafisa has been selling cloth and lace materials for a year now. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. She treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods. For lack of adequate working capital, she buys few lace materials and lengths of cloth and sells through hawking. For this reason she requests loan support to make business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level.

With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk supplies of lace materials, cloth and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to enter the university in the next academic year. She also belongs to the village bank called ‘Asomdwe’ which means Peace.

loans.use: To purchase bulk supplies of lace materials and textiles

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Mrs. Joan M.  has been a Paglaum member in good standing at Golden Center for more than 3 years, since April 2006. Married and blessed with 2 children, her husband is a farmer. Recently, she's requesting her loan in the amount of 6,000 php for the purpose of purchasing fertilizers and chemicals for their rice field. Lastly, she is very glad to be doing her daily work for the good of her rice field because this is one of their sources of income for their daily needs.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Somaila

texts.en:
Somaila, 35 years old and a trader, is married and the father of three children. All the kids are currently in school. His wife sells cosmetics products through hawking. He is a very resourceful father whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family.

Somalia supports his kids through the sale of used clothing. Selling of used clothing has a very big market share in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor, and he has being in this business for the past two years. He travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase his stock of goods. He wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase his inventory. He normally concentrates on kids' wear, men's wear, and used towels sales. He believes this loan would help him save for his children’s future and also to rent a store as he sells through hawking all day. He would be grateful for your assistance. He also belongs to the village bank called ‘Asomdwe’ which means Peace.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing

loans.name: Cherrylyn

texts.en: Mrs. Cherrylyn M. is a bonafide resident of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. Married and blessed with 2 children, she started her business with their own capital together with her sister. Their customers are mostly their  neighbors and passers-by. The status of her store is stable and progressing, expanding and full of stock. Recently, she's requesting her loan in the amount of 3,000 that will be used to buy additional stock. Her future plan is to have branches in other municipalities. And for her family, that her children will be able to finish their studies and become successful in their profession.

loans.use: to buy additional stock

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr: L. Maïmouna est née vers 1976 dans la Commune de Bassila dans le Département de la Donga au Nord du Bénin. Maïmouna est mariée et mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés et à la charge de son mari et elle. Maïmouna vend à manger au carrefour Abattoir, un grand carrefour situé dans le quartier Akpakpa à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Maïmouna vend en effet du piron rouge (fait à base de la farine de manioc), de la pâte rouge (fait à base de la farine de maïs), de l'acassa (fait à base de l'amidon de maïs) ainsi que du riz et du haricot. Maïmouna a déjà eu deux crédits de ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a très bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener son activité à un stade supérieur. Aujourd’hui encore Maïmouna sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter le volume de son activité afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle sans cesse croissante.
texts.en:
L. Maïmouna was born around 1976 in the town of Bassila, in Donga County in northern Benin. She is married and the mother of four children who are all in school and supported by her and her husband. Maïmouna sells food to eat at the Abattoir crossroad, located in the Akpakpa district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Basically, she sells red piron (a mash made with cassava flour), red mash (made with cornmeal), acassa (balls made with fermented cornstarch), as well as rice and beans. Maïmouna has already had two loans with ALIDÉ and has indeed repaid them, having used them to bring her business to a higher level. Today, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDÉ to increase her business volume in order to do better in satisfying her ever-growing customer base.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a 50-kg sack of cassava flour, three 50-kg sacks of corn, a 50-kg sack of rice, another of beans, 25 liters of peanut oil, and some sauce condiments

loans.name: Jovencia

texts.en: Mrs. Jovencia B. is 51 years old, a widow and blessed with 6 children. She is a bonafide resident of Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She has only 1 child living with her, in school, and the rest already have their own work. Recently, she's requesting her 1st loan in the amount of 3,000 php that will be used to buy additional stock for her existing project. Her future plan for her business is widen the space at the public market and for her family is that her children will have their stable lives and independence; she is hoping to have a concrete house. She's thankful to the PMPC because they were able to provide capital and extend insurance and savings where a savings account is non-taxable.

loans.use: additional capital for her "sari-sari" (variety) store

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en: Mrs. Lenie A. is one of the thousands of members of Paglaum, and she is a member in good standing who joined in April 2004. She lives in Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, is married, and blessed with four children, three in elementary and one who is one-year old. Mrs. A. is requesting a loan to help her and her husband cultivate their rice field. The loan will be used to purchase fertilizers, chemicals, and to pay for the laborer needed to help with growing their crop. Mrs. A. is very inspired and thank to Paglaum MPC for giving her the opportunity to borrow money that helps her and her family improve their daily lives.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer/chemicals for rice production

loans.name: Jeselyn

texts.en: Mrs. Jeselyn C. has been a member of Paglaum Coop since October 30, 2000. She is a resident of Upper Bunawan, Calamba Misamis Occidental, is married to Mr. Danice C., and blessed with three children. She used income from her coconut tree business to open a sari sari (general store). Now she is requesting a loan so she can improve her store and her income.  She hopes to send her children through school and college so they will be able to find decent, stable jobs.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Nazya Group

texts.en:
Nazya is the group leader of the Nazya group, which has three members. To expand their businesses, they requested a loan of 15000 Afghani. Nazya wants to take a loan to make her hairdressing shop larger. Parwen wants a loan to buy a new machine for her business of tailoring. And Aqa jan wants to buy necessary materials for his vegetable shop.

They all are happy about the process of the loan and want to say that it can support the entrepreneurs a lot.

loans.use: To make their businesses larger

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Mrs. Merlyn J.  is 49-years old and an active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP Program. She is married to Leopoldo J. and they are presently residing in Gotocan Daku, Ozamiz City. They are blessed with seven children, only three remain dependent upon them and are presently studying in high school. Her husband is a government employee at City Engineers Office and assigned to the Road Maintenance Division. Another source of their income comes from their little cornland. However, her husband’s present income and their farm income is not enough to support their family needs, so Mrs. J. is opened a small sari-sari (general store) two years ago. Her business is progressing nicely, and she is requesting a loan so she continue to grow her business. She is hoping that all her children can finish their studies so they can have a good future. For her, there is always hope in PAGLAUM and KIVA.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing Sari-sari Store

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity E. sells clothes and sarongs. She is 32-years old and married with one child. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell. Having more merchandise will increase her income and help her business service more customers. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B. is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, four sons a daughter. All of her children are currently in junior high and primary schools. She lives with her husband and her children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Victoria is a trader. She trades in eggs. She procures crates of eggs from poultry farms in her community and nearby communities at affordable prices and sells in the local market. She also treks to other towns to sell. She distributes some to retailers and beverage sellers. She has been in business for four years and is requesting a loan to procure crate of eggs in bulk. Victoria hopes to continue to expand her business so she can give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy eggs in bulk

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Benkadi est  constitué de sept femmes dont quatre monogames et trois polygames  qui ont en  moyenne  30 ans et  3 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau qui est l’une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  des condiments alimentaires, des pagnes wax, des produits de beauté,  des savons etc. 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin  de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leurs  clientèles  et d’accroitre leur profit. Les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  20 cartons de savons, 30 paniers de condiments alimentaires, 30 pièces de pagnes wax et 50 cartons de produits de beauté.
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans la nourriture  et l’habillement des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi  ambitionnent de devenir des  grossistes à Bougoula hameau.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed of seven women (four monogamous and three polygamous) who average 30 years of age and 3 children each. The women live in the hamlet of Bougoula, which is a rural community of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including selling condiments, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), beauty products, soaps, etc. The group members are on their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the growing needs of their customers and to increase their profits. The preceding loans have been repaid. With the current loan, they intend to buy 20 boxes of soap, 30 baskets of condiments, 30 bolts of Wax pagnes, and 50 boxes of beauty products. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold there too, locally, at home, and door-to-door, cash or credit accepted at the retail level. Their customers are composed of women and men. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for feeding and clothing the children, and the other portion will be invested in business and used for making loan payments. Their ambition is to become wholesalers in the hamlet of Bougoula.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora L. is from the city of Mobod, Oroquieta City. She is 62-years old. Nora is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns and operates copra-buying business in the agriculture sector where crops are raised. Copra comes from coconuts, and planting and harvesting coconut trees is basic to this business. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 49 years.

In 2001, Nora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nora is requesting a loan  to pay for services to increase her crop yield. This loan will be the 14th loan taken out by Nora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Olushola

texts.en: Olushola is 39-years old and married with four children. She is in the business of selling fruits, and she is requesting a loan in order to increase her inventory which will enable her to service more customers and to increase her income. Olushola says thank you to KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits to sell

loans.name: Afi Sénam

texts.fr:
Cette dame a ouvert une  boutique dans laquelle elle vend du matériel de bureau, elle fait aussi dans sa boutique du traitement de texte, des impressions sur papiers et la vente de matériel informatique. Elle veut commencer la vente de cartes de recharges et augmenter son stock de marchandises c’est pour cela qu’elle s’adresse à WAGES pour demander son premier crédit afin d’acheter 5 cartons de cartes de recharges et divers matériaux de bureau.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
This is a lady who opened a shop where she sells office supplies. There also, she offers word-processing, printing on paper, and computer supplies. She wants to start selling mobile phone recharge cards and to augment her stock of merchandise. For these reasons, she is inquiring with WAGES to ask for her first loan, in order to buy five boxes of recharge cards and various office supplies. She is married and the mother with a child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mobile phone cards and office supplies

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Danaya est  constitué de cinq femmes  mariées dont quatre sont polygames et une monogame qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de savons,  du bois de chauffe, des pagnes de différentes sortes et  des céréales. 
Elles sont à leur  quatrième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin de la  clientèle et augmenter leur profit. Les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  20 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, 40 cartons de savons et 30 sacs de céréales. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place,  à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Danaya  ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
This Danaya group is made up of 5 married women of whom 4 are polygamous and the other monogamous, with an average age of 35 and on average 2 children. They live in Bougoula hamlet, one of the rural communities of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have diverse businesses, among others selling soap, firewood, various sorts of "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) and cereals.

They are on their fourth loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele and increase their profit. The preceding loans have all been reimbursed correctly.

With this loan, they intend to buy 20 wagonloads of firewood, 40 cases of soap, and 30 sacks of cereals. They stock up in the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold in the big market of Sikasso town where they live, out of their homes, and door-to-door to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash, retail and on credit.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 22,000 F CFA of which part will be used to help their husbands support their families and the rest will be reinvested into their businesses and used to repay the loan. The ambition of the women of the Danaya group is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Ata

texts.en: Ata Y. is 35-years old. He is married and has three children, two sons and a daughter. The children are in junior high and primary schools. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. His wife is a seamstress. Ata is a herbalist. From local herbs, he manufactures ointments and concoctions which he distributes to drug store operators in his community. He also hawks and treks to other towns to sell his products. He procures his raw materials from Dormaa, the district capital. Ata has been in business for seven years and is requesting a loan to procure raw materials in bulk. He is hopeful to expand his business and give his children the best of education he can afford.

loans.use: To buy herbs in bulk

loans.name: Eddy

texts.en: Eddy sells provisions and drinks. He is 35-years old and married with three children. He is requesting a loan to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. Increasing his inventory will improve his income by enabling him to service more customers and build a bigger customer base. He says thank you all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Jiguisseme est  constitué de quatre femmes mariées toutes monogames ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 2 enfants et  habitant à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin croissant des  clients et d’accroitre leurs revenus. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments alimentaires, de haricot et bien d’autres céréales.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  40 colis de condiments alimentaires et 50 sacs  de 100 kg de céréales . Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant et en détail.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’éducation et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Jiguisseme ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
This Jiguisseme group is made up of four married women, all monogamous, with an average age of 35 and on average two children. They live in Bougoula hamlet, one of the rural communities of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali).

They are on their 5th loan through the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, so as to satisfy the ever-growing needs of their customers and increase their income. All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. They have varied businesses, among others selling condiments, dried beans, and various other cereals.

With this loan, they intend to buy 40 containers of condiments and 50 sacks of 100 kg of cereals. They stock up at the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold at the Sikasso city market right where they live, out of their homes, and door-to-door to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash, retail.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 19,000 F CFA of which part will be used for the health and education of their children and the rest reinvested into their businesses or used to reimburse the loan. The ambition of the women of this Jiguisseme group is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments and cereals for resale

loans.name: Kigongo Teopista ‘S Group

texts.en:
Teopista is the leader of a loan group with five members. She is widowed with four children aged between 21and 30 years. None of her children go to school .She resides in and owns a six-room house which houses six people. Teopista also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to piped water and eats three meals a day Teopista sells sweet bananas in the Nakawa market and she sells to an average of 20 customers a day. She has been in this business for fourteen years.and works six days a week. Teopista has been with MCDT for six years with the same group mates  She is requesting her 12th loan to buy more bananas and she hopes to begin to buy them directly from farmers and increase her profit by reducing her purchase costs.
  

 


  

4-Najiba Damalie 
5- N. Mary

loans.use: To buy more bananas for resale

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa F. is forty two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, one son and three daughters. She says some are in the junior high school while others are in the primary schools. She lives with her children and husband in a family house in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a farmer.

Theresa is a food vendor. She prepares and sells porridge. She prepares the porridge in her house of residence and sells it in her community in the mornings. Theresa procures bags of maize from the nearby communities. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure bags of maize

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognogontala est constitué de sept femmes mariées toutes monogames qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali).  
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de poissons,  de tasses, de  tissus,  des condiments alimentaires et  des céréales. 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin de la  clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  20 colis de condiments, 30 sacs  de 100 kg de céréales, 10 pièces  de pagnes wax et  20 paniers de poissons. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, dans les villages environnants, à  Mopti  (cinquième région administrative du Mali) et au Burkina Faso (un  pays frontalier du Mali). Les marchandises sont vendues dans les différents marchés de Sikasso ville, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, en détail et surtout au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’habillement et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
The Kotognogontala group is made up of seven married women all monogamous who are on average 37 years old and average three children each. They live in the hamlet of Bougoula, one of the rural villages in Sikasso (third administrative region in Mali).

They conduct various activities, among others the sale of fish, cups, fabric, condiments, and cereals.

This is their fifth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the customers demand that keeps on rising. All the previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

With this loan they would like to buy 20 boxes of condiments, 30 100kg bags of cereals, 10 pieces of pagnes Wax [traditional wrap around fabric] and 20 baskets of fish. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of the town of Sikasso, in the surrounding villages , in Mopti (fifth administrative region of Mali) and in Burkina Fasso (a country neighboring Mali). The goods are sold on the various markets in the town of Sikasso, from home, and door to door to customers made up of women and men. They sell retail and above all for cash.

They are planning to each make an average monthly profit of 23,000 CFA [about $50]. One part will be used for the clothing and health care of the children and the other will be invested in the business and the repayment of the loan.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various goods

loans.name: Muzafar

texts.ru: Музафар Ахмедов проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 35 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Музафар имеет торговую точку на рынке "Мехргон". Он более 7 лет занимается торговлей овощей.  Клиент просит у нас кредит, чтобы закупить сезонные овощи, для продажи.
texts.en:
Muzafar A. lives in the Yavan area. He is 35 years old, married with 3 children. Muzafar has a stall at the Mehrgon market. He has been selling vegetables for over 7 years. He is asking for a loan to buy more seasonal vegetables so as to increase his inventory and sales.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Increase Inventory of Seasonal Vegetables

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria E. is 30 years old and married with 4 children. She has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods. She hopes for the loan amount of N 30,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is thirty nine years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, one son and three daughters. She says some are in the junior high school while others are in the primary schools. She lives with her children and husband in a family house in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Felicia is a food vendor. She prepares and sells ‘banku’. Banku is prepared from corn dough. It is served hot with soup. She prepares the food in her house of residence and sells on a table at the community market. Felecia procures bags of maize and other ingredients from the nearby communities. She has been in business for sixteen years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure bags of maize

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouma est constitué de six femmes mariées toutes monogames ayant en moyenne 38 ans et  4 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  des céréales,  des tissus, des pagnes  wax, et  des condiments alimentaires. 
Elles sont à leur  quatrième   collaboration avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin de leurs  clientèles et augmenter leurs revenus. Les prêts précédents ont été tous correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter  40 sacs de 50 kg de  céréales et  50 colis de condiments. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit, dans les différents marchés de la ville de Sikasso, à domicile et de façon ambulante. La clientèle  est composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris  à construire et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
The group Sabougnouma is composed of six married women, all monogamous, who average 38 years of age and 4 children each. The women live in the hamlet of Bougoula, a rural community of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including the sale of grains, fabrics, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), and condiments. They are on their fourth collaboration with the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer demand and to increase their revenues. The preceding loans have all been correctly repaid. With this new loan, the group members intend to buy forty 50-kg sacks of grain and fifty packages of condiments. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold retail, in cash transactions and often on credit, at the different markets of Sikasso City, out of the house, and door-to-door. The customers are composed of women and men. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs. A portion will be used to help the husbands with construction, and the other portion will be invested in business and used for making loan payments.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain and condiments

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour is a tailor. He is 37 years old and married with 3 children. He hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Kyarwabuyamba A Basigirenda Topista Group

texts.en: B. Topista is 25 years old and married with two children, one of them going to school. She has dealt in soft drinks for one year so far. She is using the loan to purchase passion fruits for squeezing, sodas, water, Safi, splash etc. She is a courageous lady whose dream is to work hard to obtain a plot of land, construct a house and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase passion fruits for squeezing, sodas, water, Safi, splash etc.

loans.name: Shiringul

texts.ru: Ширингул Давлатова более 10 лет занимается торговлей. Она имеет собственный продуктовый магазин. Замужем, имеет 8 детей. Муж находится на заработках в России, он также каждый месяц высылает деньги. Проживает она в районе Явана. По бизнесу ей помогают дети. Клиентка просит у нас кредит, чтобы закупить продукты питания.
texts.en:
Shiringul D. has worked for over 10 years in retail. She owns her own grocery store. She is married and has eight children, who help with the business. Her husband is working in Russia, and sends money home every month. She lives in the Yavan district. Shiringul is requesting a loan to stock up on groceries for the store.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Safina Nakalema‘S Group

texts.en: Safina is the leader of a group with 4 members. She is a 49-year-old married woman with five children between the ages of 12 and 20. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a one-room house where she is staying with three people. Safina takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Safina operates a restaurant in Nakulabye, one of Kampala's suburbs. She sells to all kinds of customers, serving an average of 20 people a day. She works six days a week. Safina buys all the food she requires from Nakulabye market and doesn't pay extra for transportation to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses are rent for the business premises and her residence. She has been in this business for the last two years. Her main challenge is the rainy season, which stops her customers from coming to her restaurant. Safina has been with MCDT for over two years and is requesting her fourth loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more saucepans, plates, and cups. She aspires to open up another eating joint.

loans.use: To buy saucepans, plates, and cups

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth Y. is 20 years old. She is married and has given birth to one son who has yet to start school. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a farmer. Elizabeth is a trader. She trades in second-hand textiles like ladies underwear. She hawks to sell and also treks to other towns to sell. Elizabeth procures bales of textiles from Dormaa, the district capital. She has been in business for one year and wants a loan to procure textiles in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy textiles

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en: Loveth O. is 30 years old and single with no children. She is a hairstylist. She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase a generator. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a generator

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama B. is 33 years old. She is a married woman with three children, one daughter and two sons. She says her children are currently in junior high and primary schools. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a farmer.

Ama trades in smoked fish. She procures smoked fish from Dormaa and sells it in the local market on a tabletop. She also treks to other towns to sell. Ama also trades in vegetables. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She hopes to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure smoked fish

loans.name: Kyarwabuyamba A Kisembo Sifah Group

texts.en: K. Sifah is age 30 and married with four children, all schooling. She sells produce, so far for five years. She is using the loan to purchase produce (beans, maize, rice, millet and ground nuts) thus adding stock to her business. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to construct a house and own a car.

loans.use: To purchase produce to add stock to her business

loans.name: Sérieux Group

texts.fr:
Sérieux est un groupe constitué de sept femmes dont trois monogames et quatre polygames qui ont en moyenne 32 ans et  3 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali).  
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de condiments alimentaires, de  pagnes wax, des  fruits et  des céréales.
Elles sont à leur  sixième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin croissant des  clients  et d’accroitre leurs revenus. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  30 colis de condiments alimentaires, 30 sacs  de 100 kg de céréales  et  25 paniers de fruits.  Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans  les villages environnants auprès des producteurs. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place,  à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant et en détail.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’éducation et  la santé des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Sérieux ambitionnent d’entreprendre des voyages d’affaire en vue d’élargir leur horizon.
texts.en:
Sérieux is a group composed of seven women (3 monogamous and 4 polygamous) who average 32 years of age and 3 children each. The women live in the hamlet of Bougoula, a rural community of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including the sale of condiments, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), fruit, and grains. They are on their sixth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer demand and to grow their revenues. All of the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With this loan, they intend to buy thirty packages of condiments, thirty 100-kg sacks of grain, and 25 baskets of fruit. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in surrounding villages from producers. The merchandise is sold retail in cash transactions at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City locally, out of the house, and door-to-door. The customers are composed of women and men. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA. A portion will be used for the education and health of the children, and the other portion will be invested in business and used for making loan payments. Their ambition is to embark on business trips with the aim of expanding their horizons.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Yaw

texts.en:
Yaw B. is twenty-eight years old. He is single but has one child, a son. He says his son is currently in the primary school. He lives with his son in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Yaw is a trader, trading in cereals - maize. He procures bags of maize from farmers in the nearby communities and sells in the local market to retailers and food vendors. He also treks to other towns to sell.

Yaw has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk. He is hopeful to expand his business and give his child the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize in bulk

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.ru: Иброгимов Баходур более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Возраст 27 лет. Проживает в районе Явана. Баходур покупает крупно рогатый скот откармливает и перепродает. Этот вид бизнеса является единственным источником дохода. Клиент просит у нас кредит, чтобы купить дойную корову. И в дальнейшем продавать молоко.
texts.en:
Bahodur I. has practiced animal husbandry for over five years. He is 27 years old, married, and has three children. He lives in the Yavan district. Bahodur buys cattle to fatten then resell.
