The business provides his sole source of income. He is requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow so that he will be able to sell milk in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dairy cow

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Sinignessigui  est  constitué de sept femmes monogames  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires,  des pagnes wax, du  bois de chauffe et des chaussures. 
Elles sont à leur  troisième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant des  clients  et d’accroitre leurs revenus. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce nouveau prêt,  25 paniers de condiments, 40 pièces de pagnes wax, 10 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe et 80 paires de chaussures. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes  et dans les villages environnants auprès des producteurs. Les marchandises sont vendues dans les marchés de la ville de  Sikasso, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes  généralement au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 21 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans la nourriture et l’habillement des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Sinignessigui ambitionnent  devenir des  grossistes et effectuer des voyages entre le Mali et les pays frontaliers.
texts.en:
The group Sinignessigui is composed of seven monogamous women who average 33 years of age and 2 children each. The women live in the hamlet of Bougoula, a rural community of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including the sale of condiments, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), firewood, and shoes. They are on their third collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of satisfying the growing customer demand and increasing their revenues. All of the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With this new loan, the group members intend to buy 25 baskets of condiments, forty bolts of Wax pagnes, ten cart-loads of firewood, and eighty pairs of shoes. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City from wholesalers and in surrounding villages from producers. The merchandise is sold in cash transactions generally, at the marketplaces of Sikasso City, out of the house, and door-to-door. The customers are composed of women and men. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 21,000 francs CFA. A portion will be used for feeding and clothing the children, and the other portion will be invested in business and used for making loan payments. Their ambition is to become wholesalers and to make trips between Mali and the bordering countries.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Margaret Nakawoojwa‘S Group

texts.en:
Margaret is the leader of four members of a group. She is 47 years old and widowed with five children aged between 18 and 26 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she is staying with seven people. Margaret takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Margaret resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Margaret sells secondhand clothes in Kalerwe Market, in one of Kampala’s suburbs. She sells to an average of ten people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week.

Margaret buys clothes from Owino Market, one of busiest markets in Uganda and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include rent for both the business premises and residence, school fees and medication. She has been in this business for the last fifteen years. Prior to her clothing business she sold chips (french fries) in the evening. Her main challenges are the rainy season, which stops her customers from coming to her, and defaulters.

Margaret has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes and a bag of Irish potatoes for chips. Margaret is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning permanent premises.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes and a sack of Irish potatoes for chips

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
Abdul R., 28 years old, is married and has two sons and a daughter. He tells us the children are all in the primary school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase, which is a farming and trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. His wife is a trader.

Abdul is a teacher by profession, but he also trades as well. He sells provisions on a tabletop in front of his house. Abdul procures his products from Dormaa. He has been in business for two years.

He has requested a loan to procure provisions in bulk. He is eager to expand his business and hopes to give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To procure provisions in bulk for sale

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Ben est constitué de quatre femmes (dont trois mariées et une veuve) ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3 ème région administrative de la république du Mali).  
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente des tissus, des pagnes wax,  des chaussures  et des  condiments alimentaires.  
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et d’augmenter leurs profits , elles décidèrent de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt servira à acheter,  25 pièces de pagnes  wax,  40 paires de chaussures et  20 paniers de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Bamako,  de Médine à Sikasso ville et dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues  plupart au comptant, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les familles à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
The Ben Group is composed of four women (three of whom are married and one is a widow), who are, on average, 35 years old and have two children. The majority of the women live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They run diverse businesses, which sell, among other things, fabric, pagnes (traditional wrap-arounds), shoes, and food seasonings.

In order to satisfy the needs of their clientele and to increase their profits, they decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, from whom they received their first group loan.

This loan will serve to buy 25 pieces of pagnes , 40 pairs of shoes, and 20 baskets of food seasonings. The women get their supplies in the markets of Bamako, Médine, and in Sikasso city and the neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold primarily in cash in Sikasso’s different markets and in families. The clientele is generally composed of women.

The women expect that each will achieve an average monthly benefit of 18,000 FCA of which a part will be used for their families’ needs. The other part will be invested in the businesses and repayment of the loans.

Translated from French by Andrew Whiteman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various goods

loans.name: Emmanuella

texts.en:
Emmanuella Y. is 25 years old. She is married and one child, a daughter who is currently in the primary school. Emmanuella lives with her husband and child in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase, which is a farming and trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a farmer.

Emmanuella is a trader. She trades in secondhand textiles, specifically ladies’ underclothing and dresses. She hawks her wares in her neighborhood and also treks to other towns to sell. She procures bales of textiles from Dormaa. She has been in business for three years.

She hopes to receive a loan to procure her textiles in bulk. She is eager to expand her business and to help improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy secondhand textiles in bulk

loans.name: Yahshibek

texts.ru: Темиров Яшибек проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 32 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Яшибек более 3 лет занимается торговлей. Он торгует автозапчасти. Этот вид бизнеса является основным источником дохода. Клиент просит у нас кредит, чтобы купить запчасти для тракторов.
texts.en:
Yashibek T. lives in the Yavan district. He is 32 years old, married, and has three children. Yashibek has worked in retail for over three years. He sells spare auto parts. The business is his sole source of income. He is requesting a loan to buy spare parts for tractors.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
To earn a living, Helen I. sells provisions and drinks. Helen is 43 years old and married with five children.

She hopes to receive a loan in the amount of N60,000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell.

She sends her gratitude to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell.

loans.name: Pabouke Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Pabouke est constitué de quatre  femmes mariées toutes monogames  ayant en moyenne  32 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye,  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3 ème région administrative de la république  du Mali). 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autre la vente des condiments alimentaires,  des chaussures  et  des pagnes wax.  
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et d’augmenter leur profit, elles ont décidé de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter  40 pièces de pagnes  wax,  50 paires de chaussures, 60 paniers de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Bamako, de Médine à Sikasso ville et dans  les localités avoisinantes.  Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant, dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les familles à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12 500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
The Pabouke Group is composed of four married women who are, on average 32 years old and have three children. The majority of the women live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They run diverse businesses, which sell, among other things, food seasonings, shoes, and pagnes (traditional wrap-arounds).

In order to satisfy the needs of their clientele and to increase their profits, they decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, from whom they received their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy 40 pieces of pagnes, 50 pairs of shoes, and 60 baskets of food seasonings. The women get their supplies from the markets of Bamako, Médine, and in Sikasso city and the neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold primarily in cash in the different markets of Sikasso and in families. The clientele is composed of men and women. The women expect that each will achieve an average monthly benefit of 12,500 FCFA of which a part will be used for their families’ needs. The other part will be invested in the businesses and repayment of the loans.

Translated from French by Andrew Whiteman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various goods

loans.name: Veaceslav

texts.en:
In 2005, Veaceslav started a small timber operation in the south of Moldova. Veaceslav's entry into the timber business was in the trade flow from Romania to Moldova at that time and he has since posted an impressive growth rate, particularly over the past two years.

During this period, Veaceslav has become one of the larger suppliers in the region. This strong business growth is the result of his strength in the three key dimensions of the business: sourcing, depth of product species, and marketing presence. He places a significant emphasis on quality control, and this is reflected in his quality management systems and procedures. His objective is to enhance value through providing superior service to his customers.

Veaceslav recognizes that it requires long-term commitment to improve forestry practices, so he has requested a micro-loan from Microinvest to purchase more logging and tree-felling equipment.

loans.use: To purchase more logging and tree-felling equipment

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen A. is eighty-two years old. He is married and has six children: three daughters and three sons. He lives with his wife and some grandchildren in a family apartment in a town called Kofiase, which is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Stephen says his children are all grown and live independently. His wife is a farmer and food vendor.

Stephen is a commercial driver. He drives a Urvan bus (a small Nissan vehicle). He conveys goods and people to and from his community and other nearby communities. He works from morning to the evening. He says his bus, which is his only source of income, is virtually broken down and so wants a loan to have it repaired and maintained. Stephen has been driving for over twenty-five years. He is hopeful to maintain the bus and improve upon his standard of living.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle

loans.name: Drocelle

texts.en:
Greetings from Drocelle M., a 56 year old widow of 5 children of the  following ages: 30, 27, 23, 19, and 17. She lives together with her 3 younger children in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda.

Ms. M. has a transportation business in Kigali city and other villages near Kigali city. She owns a motorcycle. She has one full time employee who rides this motorcycle and produces the monthly profit of approximately $146. The daily business starts at 7:00 A.M and finishes at 8:00 P.M everyday. The requested loan is 240000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company, a partner of World Vision International.
This entrepreneur will buy a cow with the loan and from the increased profit she will get more food for her family and have more savings.

loans.use: Buying a cow

loans.name: Zebunisso

texts.ru: Зебуниссо Самадова проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 34 года. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Зебуниссо имеет магазин на торговом рынке "Мехргон". Она торгует продуктами питания. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 4 лет. Ее муж работает водителем маршрутного такси. Клиентка просит у нас кредит, чтобы закупить новые товары.
texts.en:
Zebunisso S. lives in the Yavan district. She is 34 years old, married, and has two children. Zebunisso has a store in the Mehrgon market where she sells groceries. She has been working in this type of business for over four years. Her husband is a minibus taxi driver. This client is requesting a loan to buy new goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales volume

loans.name: Zafar

texts.ru: Назралиев Зафар проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 36 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Зафар имеет торговую точку на рынке "Мехргон". Он занимается торговлей. Этим видом бизнеса он занимается более 3 лет. Клиент просит у нас кредит, чтобы закупить сезонные овощи для прожажи.
texts.en:
Zafar N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 36 years old, married, and has four children. Zafar has a vendor space at the Mehrgon market where he sells vegetables. He has worked in this type of business for over three years. He is requesting a loan to buy seasonal vegetables for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales volume

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is 45 years old and married with 3 children. She sells crates of drinks and sachet water. She hopes for a loan amount of N70, 000 to purchase a fridge to cool her drinks and sachet water. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Greetings from Mr. Eric I., a  27 year-old married man. He and his wife having 2 children of 6 and 3 years old. He lives in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda.

Eric owns a plot in Nyabugogo market where he sells shoes. He has  12 years experience in this business and he has 1 full time employee who helps him in this business. He starts his daily operations at 8h00 A.M and finishes at 8:00 P.M.
Until now Eric has had a profit of approximately $220 per month He is requesting his first loan of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company, a division of World Vision International. With the loan, Eric will buy more shoes to expand his store and from the increased profit he will still be reinvesting in his business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana G. runs a business in domestic vegetable growing as the primary source of her family's income.Shee owns two greenhouses on a surface of 15 hectares. Ana has been working in vegetable farming  for more than 10 years. She grows tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers and eggplants. Business is profitable as she focuses on reducing costs of production. She is the mother of three children who are the source of inspiration for their parents. Ana is seeking a loan through Microinvest  to purchase film to finish construction of other two greenhouses. Ana is grateful to Microinvest and Kiva for the trust and financial support.

loans.use: For purchasing film for greenhouse construction

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en:
Greetings from Epiphanie Z. , a 32 year-old married woman. She and her husband have 3 children and 1 orphan of following respective ages: 10, 7, 3 and 12 years old. Epiphanie and her family live in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the city capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur owns a butcher shop in the Nyarugenge district. Her business is to sell meat.Epiphanie  has 2 workers to help her to run this business well. She has 5 years of experience in this business sector.  She starts working at 5:00 A.M and finishes at 7:00 P.M. Epiphane receives a  profit of $550 per month from this business. She is requesting a loan of 500000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company, a partner of World Vision International.
Epiphanie hopes to expand her business and from the increased profit she intends to reinvest in the same business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Lusaka Upper A Nyadera Regina Group

texts.en:
Regina N., the group leader of this loan, is 45 years of age. She is married with seven children, of whom four are in school. She also looks after three additional dependents. She has been in her business for over 22 years. She began with very little capital and bought a sewing machine, which she still owns and uses.

Regina would like to use this loan to purchase material to make school uniforms and other kinds of clothes. She is a hardworking woman whose dream is to purchase a modern sewing machine and expand her designs and products.

loans.use: To purchase material to make clothing such as school uniforms for sale

loans.name: Valeriu

texts.en:
This is Valeriu, who has run his own business for many years. He would like to increase his stock of goods as well as to purchase seeds and build a greenhouse for cultivation. Microinvest has granted him a loan to buy the necessary wood and film for the greenhouse.

In the future, Valeriu would like to raise sheep. He plans to obtain the money to enter into this area of business by taking out another loan from Microinvest. This will happen after he repays his current loan.

We wish him the best of luck and would like to see him succeed in his business ventures.

loans.use: To purchase wood and film for greenhouse construction

loans.name: Esperance

texts.en:
Greetings from Mrs. M. Esperance, a Rwandan entrepreneur aged 39 years. She is a married woman, she and her husband having four children and two orphans, respectively of the following ages: 17, 16, 12, 4, 18 and 12 years old. Her husband produces a monthly income of $730.

Mrs. M. operates her business in Nyarugenge district where she owns a store and sells sacs of charcoal to the population and restaurants which operate at that place.

The loan amount being requested is 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company and it will be her first loan. She has one worker to help her in this business and she has experience of seven years in the business and obtains a profit of approximately $275 per month. She starts working at 6:00 a.m. and finishes at 8:00 p.m. every day.

Mrs. M. hopes to expand her business through the loan and she will reinvest the increased profit in the same business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Margaret Namujju‘S Group

texts.en:
Margaret, age 40, is the leader of a group of five members. She is the single mother of four children between the ages of 14 and 20. All her children go to school. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with her children. There is electricity and piped water at her home and she ensures that the family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Margaret sells secondhand clothes door to door. She sells to an average of 20 people a day, and she works seven days a week. Margaret buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in the city of Kampala. Her major monthly expenses include rent, electricity, and medication. She also incurs extra transportation costs to and from the market. She has been in this business for the last 20 years and sells to all categories of people. Her main challenges are the increasing prices of clothes and seasonal ups and downs in sales. Prior to this business, Margaret was selling charcoal.

She has been with MCDT for over six years. She and her fellow group mates have received and repaid 11 loans before this one.

Margaret wants to use this loan to buy a bale of clothes. She aspires tocontinue to improve her business and dreams of owning a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O. is a tailor. She also earns some income by selling sarongs. She is 39 years old and married with two children.

Rosie hopes for a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase more material and more sarongs to sell.

She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs for sale

loans.name: Lusaka Upper A Bakyanibera Grace Group

texts.en:
Grace B., age 44, is the group leader of this loan group. She is the single mother of four children, three of whom are going to school. She has been in the business of selling clothes for over seven years.

She has requested a loan to purchase used clothes such as jackets, raincoats, children's clothes, and shoes for sale. She is a hardworking woman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes for sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 48 years old and married with five children. She sells provisions, drinks, and firewood to make a living.

She hopes to obtain a loan in the amount of N70,000 to purchase more firewood, drinks, and provisions to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and firewood to sell

loans.name: Arame

texts.fr: Arame  K.  est  un éleveur de moutons et fait du petit commerce en même temps. Elle a aménagé dans la maison un petit enclos ou sont  élèves les moutons. Elle habite au quartier zone résidentielle à Mbour située à 70 km de Dakar. Où elle avec son époux et sa famille. Elle est âgée de   49 ans. Avec les revenus tirés de l’élevage des moutons elle participe à la dépense quotidienne  et paie le besoins de ses enfants .avec le prêt solliciter elle veut diversifier se activités en faisant du commerce  de légumes. Elle est en son premier crédit avec l IMCEC
texts.en:
Arame K. is a livestock farmer who raises sheep and also does small-scale commerce at the same time. In her house, she has fixed up a small enclosure, where the sheep are kept. She lives in the residential district of Mbour, located 70 km from Dakar, where she lives with her husband and family. She is 49 years old. With the revenues derived from raising sheep, she helps cover day-to-day family expenses and the children's needs. With the loan requested, she wants to diversify her businesses through commerce in vegetables. She is on her first loan with IMCEC.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr: Babacar WIllane est vendeur de paille d’arachides l aliment principal des ovins ; des caprins et autre ruminants. Il a quitté son village natal pour s’installer à Mbour ville côtière située à 70km de Dakar la capitale sénégalaise.les revenus tiré du commerce lui permettent d’entretenir sa femme et ses enfants restés au village avec ses parents. Il a eu à bénéficier d’un premier prêt destiné à l’achat une charrette pour le transport hippomobile. Avec le prêt qu’il solliciter il va acheter de la paille d’arachide.
texts.en:
Babacar WIllane sells peanut straw, a principal food for sheep, goats, and other ruminants. He left his native village to come and live in Mbour, a coastal town situated 70 km from Dakar, the Senegalese capital. The income from his business allows him to support his wife and children who stayed back in the village with his parents. He received a first loan to buy a wagon for horse-drawn transport. With the loan that he is now requesting, he is going to buy peanut straw.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Lusaka Upper A Mbabazi Teddy Group

texts.en:
Teddy M., 25 years old, is a bean seller. She is married with three children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of one additional dependent, also attending school.

She has been selling beans since 2008. She wishes to use her loan to purchase bags of beans for sale. She plans to expand her business to include rice as well.

Her dream is someday to purchase a plot of land and construct a residential house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase bags of beans for sale.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is 45 years old and married with five children. She sells palm oil in retail to her customers.

Felicia hopes to receive a loan in the amount of N100, 000 to purchase more palm oil to sell.

She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 37 years old and single with no children. She is a tailor. She also earns some income by selling sarongs.

She hopes to receive a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase material and sarongs to sell.

Joy sends her gratitude.

loans.use: To purchase material and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Amen is 42 years old and married with six children. She sells foodstuffs and provisions and hopes to expand her business. She hopes for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence sells clothes and sarongs. She is 34 years old and married with five children.

She is hoping to obtain a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.

She is grateful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela is a tailor and she also sells drinks. She is 35 years old and married with two children. She hopes for the loan of N40,000 to purchase a sewing machine and more drinks. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and more drinks

loans.name: Tania Marjolia

texts.es: Tania es soltera, de 34 años de edad, no tiene hijos, trabaja como administradora de un restaurante en Santo Tomas desde hace 7 años.  Esta solicitando credito para comprar 6 puertas y 6 ventanas de su vivienda para mayor seguridad, esta consciente que con el credito unicamente cubrira el 50% de la obra, pero una vez cancelado solicitara otro para finalizar lo que ella se ha propuesto, ya que su mayor ilusion es tener una vivienda amplia y con todas las condiciones necesarias.

loans.use: Compra de puertas y ventanas

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en:
Dorah A., 65 years old, is a widow with seven children. She sells sarongs and beads. She also sells beverages.

At present, her refrigerator is not working properly and she hopes to repair it. She has requested a loan in the amount of N80,000 to repair her refrigerator and to purchase more beverages to sell.

She sends her heartfelt thanks.

loans.use: To repair her refrigerator and purchase more beverages for sale

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is married with a daughter. She lives in Kherson and owns a vending facility in the central city market selling clothing. She has been in this trade for eight years. Her income has grown to 7,000 Grivnyas since she started her small business.

Yelena has a perfect credit history in Nadiya Ukraine. She has fully repaid eight loans without any delinquencies. Yelena believes a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas will help her increase her working capital and her profit as a result. She wants to purchase a variety of clothing items for sale, increase the number of products and expand her marketing area.

Yelena has become an entrepreneur through hard work and dedication which we believe will help her succeed in the future as well.

loans.use: To increase the number of products and expand her marketing area

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married with two grown children. She owns a small business selling groceries in one of the local markets in Stryi. She has one hired employee.

Galina has been in the market vending trade for 11 years. Initially, she launched a clothing sales business, and she has only recently switched to food sales as it seems to be a more sustainable venture in this time of economic recession in the Ukraine. Currently, she has about 8,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory in stock.

Galina is very enthusiastic about her new business. One of the biggest attractions of her business is the reasonable prices she offers. Galina would like to receive a loan for 8,000 Grivnyas to purchase diversified merchandise for further retail sale. These funds will allow her to maintain an adequate amount of inventory on hand and easily update her product selection.

We believe that this loan will continue to help her business be successful and provide much-needed income for Galina and her family. She is hoping to use some of her profits generated to take her family on a much-deserved vacation this summer.

loans.use: To maintain her inventory and diversify her grocery offerings

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Greetings from U. Beatrice, a 29-year-old married woman with one child aged 3 years old. She currently lives in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. This entrepreneur owns a retail shop in her district and sells different kinds of merchandise. She is earning $275 a month in profit since starting this business six months ago. She does not have employees. The shop opens at 8:00 am and closes at 8:30 pm every day. Her husband produces an income of $275 per month.

U. is requesting her first loan of 400,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company. With the loan she intends to expand her business, reinvesting her increased profits in the store.

loans.use: To invest in a store

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is married with three children. Her family lives in Stryi. Larisa started her business 14 years ago. Today she owns a little store and sells children’s supplies such as clothing, footwear, toys, and books. Her store is located next to a busy city market and is very popular in the neighborhood. Currently, she has about 60,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her net profit is about 6,000 Gryvnyas a month.

Larisa is requesting a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise wholesale. She is an experienced trade entrepreneur and has good credit history in Nadiya, Ukraine. We believe Larisa will work hard to earn an income and grow her business, offering quality inventory for her customers as well as providing decent living standards for her children, which is her ultimate goal as a mother.

One of Larisa’s long-term plans is to open another vending location someday.

Another fact about Larisa is that she uses part of her profit to help support three orphans who are under her care.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her children's supplies store

loans.name: Annonciathe

texts.en:
Greetings from M. Annonciatha, a 34-year-old married woman with five children, ages 1, 6, 7, 9, and 11. She lives in the Nyarugenge district of the city of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Mrs. M. owns a shop that offers a variety of different kinds of merchandise. At present, her husband does not earn any income. She earns a monthly proft of about $458. She has 10 years of experience in this business and has no employees. She generally starts working at 6 a.m. every morning and closes at 10 p.m. nightly.

This entrepreneur is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company. With this loan, Annonciata will buy more merchandise to increase her store's offerings.

Mrs. M. plans to reinvest the increased profit back into her business.

loans.use: To increase her store's offerings and to reinvest in her business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy A. sells firewood. She is 33 years old and married with three children.

She hopes to obtain a loan in the amount of N30,000 to purchase more firewood to sell.

She sends many thanks.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. She is a very skillful and talented hairdresser. She does all kinds of hairstyles like plaiting, perming and fixing of weavons, etc. She believes in good quality service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc. She believes this would attract more customers to her salon. 

Elizabeth is 28 years old and married with one child who is currently in school. She is a member of the community group called Sure Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and there is peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Greetings from Josephine M.. She is 35 years old and married with six children, ages 2, 5, 9, 11, 13, and 14. She also cares for one orphan of 23 years of age. Josephine and her family live in the Nyarugenge district of the city of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

This entrepreneur owns a charcoal store in the Nyarugenge district. She started her business in 2002 and she earns a monthly profit of approximately $275. She has one full-time employee who helps her in her business. In addition, her husband earns a monthly income of about $365. Mrs. Musabyiman opens her shop at 6 a.m. and closes at 8 p.m. every day.

She is seeking her first loan in the amount of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company. She plans to expand her business venture and intends to reinvest increased profits back into her business.

loans.use: To expand her venture and reinvest in her business

loans.name: Aydee Lucila

texts.es:
La señora Lucila, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Rio Desaguadero” del distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno; de 46 años de edad, con 4 hijos, posee estudios de primaria completa. 

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 13 años e inicio su negocio de venta de especerías y abarrotes con un préstamo inicial de S/.  300.00 nuevos soles.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, comprará mercadería variada (arroz, azúcar, fideos, enlatados, conservas, aceites, leche, etc.).

Manifiesta que le gusta las reuniones de pago y las capacitaciones que recibe.
texts.en:
Lucila belongs to the Rio Desaguadero Community Bank in the Desaguadero district, Chucuito province, Puno department. She is 46, and she has four children. She has an elementary school education. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for thirteen years. She started her business selling spices and groceries. She did this with an initial loan for 300 PEN. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy various merchandise like rice, sugar, noodles, canned goods, oil, milk, etc. She likes the payment meetings and the trainings she receives.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, noodles, canned goods, oil, milk, etc.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 45 years old and married with three children. Her children are currently in school. To help her husband support the family, she sells cosmetics in the local community. She has many loyal clients. She says that selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory. She believes that this will enable her to make a better income to meet her family’s needs.

Alice is a member of the group called “Odo ye de,” which means "Love is sweet." Members of the group agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Amor Y Paz - Group 3

texts.en:
Milagros C. is the group coordinator for this group of five in the Amor y Paz Bank of Hope in San Pedro de Macoris. Some of the people in her community are Haitian immigrants. Because they don't have Dominican documentation and don't speak the language well, their employment opportunities are limited, so they start their own businesses.

Milagros sells different food items at her house. Most of her sales come from basic lunch products like rice, beans, oil, and spices used to flavour food. Usually she sells small quantities from larger amounts that she purchases. She will use this loan to be well stocked in these products in order to meet the demands of her clientele.

One of Milagros' biggest challenges is collecting payments from the customers she sells to on credit. A lot of them get paid weekly or biweekly so it takes longer for her to see profits. She hopes to be able to set up a real convenience store one day.

Please help us support Milagros and her friends with this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase daily sales products like rice, beans, oil and spices
